note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

Located in Harrison County, Gulfport was founded in 1887 and serves as one of two county seats (along with Biloxi). (Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Hancock County, Gainesville was founded in 1810 and was annexed as part of Mississippi Territory on April 30, 1812. On August 1, 1812 it was merged into Mobile County, Alabama until December 18, 1812, when Gainesville became part of the newly founded Hancock County, Mississippi, where it remains today. It was incorporated in 1843 and served as the county seat from 1837 until 1853. Presently, Gainesville is a deserted town with few or no remaining inhabitants. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in central Mississippi, Copiah County was established on January 21, 1823 from Franklin, Hinds, and Lawrence counties. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in southern Mississippi, Lawrence County was established on December 22, 1814 from Marion County. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in south-central Mississippi, Covington County was established on February 5, 1819 from Lawrence and Wayne counties. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)
Located in south Mississippi, Marion County was established in 1811. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

Located in Adams County, Natchez was founded in 1716 under the name Fort Rosalie and was renamed Natchez in 1730. It became part of the newly created Adams County on April 1, 1799. It served as the capital of Mississippi Territory from 1798 until 1802, when it was replaced by Washington. It was reinstated as the capital from 1817 until 1820, when the capital was again replaced by Washington (which was later replaced by the current capital Jackson in 1822). Natchez serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: "The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Amnesty takes several forms including: "a decision made by government officials to free a prisoner," "a fixed period of time during which people are not punished for committing a particular crime," or "a decision by a government to forgive people who have committed particular illegal acts or crimes, and not to punish them." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A person who oversees "the process of managing the property, money, etc. of someone who has died and giving it to the beneficiaries." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official organization whose job is to manage a particular activity, suggest laws related to the activity, and make certain that laws are obeyed" concerning law enforcement. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where stamps are sold and from where letters and packages are sent." (Cambridge Dictionary)

div.p:
W L Sharkey
Provisional Governor of Miss

When I left Jackson I proceeded to Copiah County as you directed me & found on my arrival there that H B. Mayes the Judge of Probate of that county had taken the Amnesty oath. After a few days delay, I left that county on the 14 th inst for this (Hancock) County taking in my route Lawrence, Covington & Marion—the Probate Judge of Lawrence had gone to Natchez & I did not see him but learned that he had taken the oath—I then went to Covington & there learned that the Probate Judge of that county had gone to Jackson ^to see you^ so I did not see him from there I went to Marion & learned that the Probate Judge of that county (Judge Lewis) had taken the oath, but did not feel authorized to administer it to any

except the officers, where he got that idea from I am unable to conceive—I did not see him as he lives Some 14 miles immediately to the right of the road I had to travel but I Sent him the day I was at the County Site instructions—in reference to his duties—adding that it was his duty to be as much as possible at the court house—to give every one an opportuntity to take the oath

—I arrived here this morning—& have an opportunity by private conference to send you this note & avail myself of it I have administered the oath to the sheriff, the Probate Clerk, & three members of the Board of Police—& presume that in a few days—all the offices appointed by you will take the oath

—I have Just learned that a few of the citizens of the county living at Shieldsboro have Started a petition to you with reference to making Some Special appointments—I would by leave to state that so far as the officers who have already taken the oath that
they did it cheerfuly and that they are competent officers—
We have no mail facilities & can not now send you the copy of oaths taken before me but will transmit them at an early day
—I will here add that so far as I have gone the people are taking the amnesty oath more willingly & with a determination to abide it than I expected

I have the honor to be
Respectfully
Your Obt Sv

J B Denson
Probate Judge Heancock County

J Denson
Probate Judge Hancock
